meta.content: A fast-ion Dα (FIDA) diagnostics system was installed for core and edge measurements on KSTAR. This system has two tangential FIDA arrays that cover both blue- and redshifted Dα lines (cold: 656.09 nm) in active views along the neutral beam 1 A centerline. The spectral band is 647–662.5 nm, and it covers the Doppler shift of the emission from the maximum energy of the neutral beam (100 keV). A curved filter strip with a motorized stage adequately prevents saturation of the electron multiplying charge-coupled device signal by the cold Dα line from the plasma edge. From comparisons of the measured spectra and FIDASIM modeling code, the FIDA spectra are well matched quantitatively. Moreover, the first measurements show that the FIDA radiance agrees with the neutron rate in the time trace during external heating and perturbation. In addition, responses are observed in the core FIDA radiance during the edge-localized mode cycle.

div.div: A fast-ion Dα (FIDA) diagnostics system was installed for core and edge measurements on KSTAR. This system has two tangential FIDA arrays that cover both blue- and redshifted Dα lines (cold: 656.09 nm) in active views along the neutral beam 1 A centerline. The spectral band is 647–662.5 nm, and it covers the Doppler shift of the emission from the maximum energy of the neutral beam (100 keV). A curved filter strip with a motorized stage adequately prevents saturation of the electron multiplying charge-coupled device signal by the cold Dα line from the plasma edge. From comparisons of the measured spectra and FIDASIM modeling code, the FIDA spectra are well matched quantitatively. Moreover, the first measurements show that the FIDA radiance agrees with the neutron rate in the time trace during external heating and perturbation. In addition, responses are observed in the core FIDA radiance during the edge-localized mode cycle.
I. INTRODUCTION
Section:

While tokamak operation techniques and scenarios have developed, the investigation of supra-thermal ions has become a major issue. In particular, confined fast ions have important roles in plasma heating and current drive in larger fusion devices such as ITER and DEMO (demonstration power plant).

For FIDA diagnostics, neutrals are injected externally as a probe, and after charge exchange with fast ions, Doppler-shifted D-alpha line emission (n = 3 to n = 2) is emitted from fast neutrals. Because FIDA radiance contains information about the fast-ion density and neutrals, quantitative analysis of the measurement, along with tomographic reconstruction, is necessary. For reconstruction of the fast-ion distribution in pitch (v
||
/v) and energy space, forward modeling and deconvolutions of FIDA spectral measurement with a forward modeling output are demanding.

is presented in Sec.
I
. In Sec.
II
, the first measurement is compared to the FIDASIM synthetic spectral and radiance profile. The experimental observation, in particular, shows that fast-ion dynamics is a new candidate for the explanation about KSTAR experimental phenomena. Finally, a summary and future work are presented in the Conclusion.
II. DIAGNOSTICS SYSTEM
Section:

Two FIDA systems have been installed to cover wider velocity space.
Figure 1
shows a top view of the KSTAR tokamak with FIDA systems. Both systems are installed in J-port integrated optical modules. Lines of sight for the system are in the midplane, the only active view intersects the NBI 1 A beam line (fully tangential), and deposition is on-axis in the co-current direction. The FIDA spatial coverage of the major radius of the two systems is radially distributed on Z = 0 m from 1.82 to 2.24 m and from 1.54 to 2.27 m, respectively. Presently, each line of sight (of both systems) is allocated on the NB1-A beam line and they view blue- and red-shifted D-alpha spectra on the J-port. The two systems have 16 and 10 channels, respectively. A calibration for the radial position was performed. Each line of sight has a focal width of 30 mm, and each focal point is spatially spaced ∼40 mm and ∼100 mm for the core plasma, respectively. Doppler-shifted D
α
light reaches the FIDA spectrometer through a bundle of 600
µ
m diameter fibers. The FIDA spectrometer is shown in
Fig. 2
. This system uses an Andor iXon Ultra888 camera with an electron multiplying charge-coupled device (EMCCD) and offers a wide range of images (1024 × 1024 pixels with a pixel size of 13
µ
m and 10 MHz read out rate) with high quantum efficiency (95%) at 500–600 nm. The frame rate is 100 Hz with 2 ms exposure time, and the frame-transfer mode is utilized with multi-track binning for FIDA data acquisition. A thin neutral density filter (OD4.0) with a motorized stage is located between the imaging lens and the EMCCD camera. This filter is processed with a curved shape to hide the strong edge of the cold D-alpha line to prevent saturation of the CCD camera. Another filter (OD0.3) is also used considering the intensity of some bright discharges. The spectrometer consists of a volume-phasing holographic grism (HDG656) with 1500 groove/mm and two lenses (collecting and imaging lenses, Canon, 200 mm f/2.8). Its spectral resolution is 0.02 nm. A pixel-to-wavelength calibration is produced with H-D and Ne lamps. Target line emissions are shown in
Fig. 3
. The synthetic spectra are modeled with Voigt functions, and target peaks are linearly fitted for every channel. The spectral coverage is ∼646–662.5 nm. To convert CCD counts to photon radiance for absolute values, bremsstrahlung spectra calculated by FIDASIM are utilized. Because FIDA measures Doppler-shifted D-alpha, there are many interference emissions, and raw spectra consist of active components (such as FIDA, beam emission, and halo emission) and passive components (such as edge D-alpha and line radiation from impurities and bremsstrahlung). To subtract the passive component, beam power modulation is applied every second. The background subtraction result is introduced with the experimental results.

FIG. 1.
Top-down view of FIDA optical alignment at KSTAR.

FIG. 2.
Schematics of the FIDA spectrometers.

FIG. 3.
Measured spectra of Ne and H-D lamps and the wavelength calibration results.

The geometry of the beam and the FIDA line of sight determine the observable range of fast-ion distributions and weight function. The geometrical weight function of the core and edge FIDA01 channel is modeled with FIDASIM, as shown in
Figs. 4(a)
and
4(b)
. Because the array is fully tangential and views in the forward direction of the neutral beam, it has blue-shifted biased weight function. The edge channel shows a narrower range of weight function, and both are shown in positive pitch (v
||
/v). In this discharge, the full injection energy is 80 keV. The full, half, and one-third components are shown in the fast ion distribution calculated by TRANSP
14
14. A. Pankin, D. McCune, R. Andre, G. Bateman, and A. Kritz, Comput. Phys. Commun.
159
, 157 (2004).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cpc.2003.11.002
in
Figs. 4(c)
and
4(d)
. The convolution results of these weight and fast-ion distributions are shown in
Figs. 4(e)
and
4(f)
. This convolution corresponds to the FIDA synthetic spectra calculated by TRANSP. As mentioned before, two FIDA arrays are installed along one beam line, and FIDA02 (allocated to the end of the beam line) is expected to produce low-intensity spectra. For the feasibility check, the neutral density was calculated using FIDASIM with 70 keV neutral beam injection. The neutral density of FIDA02 is expected to be one order smaller than that of FIDA01.
Figure 5
shows the raw spectra of FIDA01 (a) and FIDA02 (b). Both show clear Doppler-shifted beam emission spectra for each channel, but the measured spectra of FIDA02 have a very narrow observable FIDA band due to large Doppler-shifted beam emission and carbon impurity line emissions. Therefore, the spectra from FIDA01 are mainly introduced with the experimental results.

FIG. 4.
Geometrical weights (top), fast-ion distributions (middle), and convolutions (bottom) of the core and edge channels of FIDA01.

FIG. 5.
Raw spectra for (a) FIDA01 (23 741) and (b) FIDA02 (23 653).
III. FIDA MEASUREMENTS
Section:

For the background subtraction, the beam power modulation technique is applied, and an example is shown in
Fig. 6
. The beam-off duration is 20 ms for discharge of 22 705, and during beam on and off time, both spectra show impurity lines such as the OV line at 650 nm and strong CII lines at 658 nm. However, after subtraction, the line emissions are clearly subtracted. For this channel, the observable FIDA spectral band is 650–653 nm, which corresponds to a parallel energy (E
||
) of 20–81 keV.

FIG. 6.
Background subtraction result with neutral beam power modulations.

The comparison between the FIDASIM of the synthetic spectra and the measurement is utilized for the absolute radiance calibration. Because the FIDA spectrometer spectral coverage is rather wide, the continuum range of the measured spectra, which is visible bremsstrahlung, is comparable to the FIDASIM bremsstrahlung spectra in photon radiance. The measured FIDA spectra are shown to be comparable to the FIDASIM synthetic spectra of the FIDA component. The results of the comparison for discharge of 23 527 is shown in
Fig. 7(a)
. The measured FIDA spectra with background subtraction and FIDASIM synthetic spectra are shown in black solid line and gray dotted line, respectively, and the results show quantitative agreement. The FIDA radiance profile comparison between FIDASIM synthetic spectra and the measurement (5-frame averaged per time slice) is shown in
Fig. 7(b)
. The FIDA radiance of FIDASIM and the measurement for the core plasma shows agreement within the error-bar range. Unfortunately, one of the channels (at rho ∼0.55) was excluded due to optical fiber problems, so the peak region of the radiance is not clearly shown. The FIDA intensity shows a trend similar to that of the neutron rate signal in the time trace. For example, as shown in
Fig. 8
, in the case of shot 22705, a decrease in the ion temperature and the toroidal rotation was caused by external magnetic perturbations (MPs) and electron cyclotron resonance heating (ECRH). 4 MW of 3 NB power was injected during the discharge, and the energy of each beam source was 81, 81, and 76 keV, respectively. A non-resonant MP was applied at 4.5 s, and its effect is clearly shown with the rotation breaking. During MP application, the FIDA intensity also decreases with the thermal ion temperature, but with electron resonance heating (ECH) at 7 s, a greater intensity drop is shown. During the discharge, the evolution of the FIDA intensity shows a trend similar to the neutron rate over time, as shown in
Fig. 8(a)
. In this series of experiments, the FIDAintensity shows a consistent time trace. Another example of the FIDA intensity response is shown in
Fig. 8(b)
with edge-localized mode (ELM). ELM spikes are shown in the D
α
signal. When the ELM crash occurs, a bulge of FIDA intensity is consistently observed in the ELMy H-mode discharges. Because an enhancement of MHDs frequently occurs between the crashes, a comprehensive investigation with observations will be presented in a subsequent study.

FIG. 7.
FIDA spectra (a) and FIDA radiance profile (b) comparisons between FIDASIM and measurement of discharge of 23 527.

FIG. 8.
FIDA signal with external heating and magnetic perturbations (a) and ELMs (b).
IV. CONCLUSIONS
Section:

The FIDA spectroscopic diagnostics system was installed for core and edge FIDA radiance measurements with a high-quantum efficiency EMCCD, which is capable of multi-channel measurements. The measured FIDA spectra show quantitative agreement with the synthetic spectra from FIDASIM, and the intensity shows agreement with the neutron rate signal in the time traces. As shown in the weight function of the KSTAR FIDA system, the observable range of pitch and energy of fast ions are limited in blue shift, even in core channels. The line of sight for FIDA02 will be modified to go along with the new NBI 2 system being commissioned at KSTAR.
15
15. J. Kwak, T. Rhee, H. Han, J. S. Kang, J. G. Bak, H. J. Ahn, Y. U. Nam, H. S. Kim, M. Kim, W. H. Ko, S. W. Yoon, W. C. Kim, and K. R. Park, IEEE Trans. Plasma Sci.
48
, 1388 (2020).
https://doi.org/10.1109/tps.2020.2964776
Therefore, to expand the coverage of velocity phase space, a new optimized view for FIDA diagnostics needs to be considered. Finally, to support a quantitative explanation for the experimental observations with FIDA radiance, tomographic reconstruction should be provided.
